abstract: Feeling jilted after six months of negotiations, German officials reacted angrily Wednesday to General Motor’s decision to keep its European business, Opel, rather than sell a majority stake to a consortium backed by Berlin.
snippet: Feeling jilted after six months of negotiations, German officials reacted angrily Wednesday to General Motor’s decision to keep its European business, Opel, rather than sell a majority stake to a consortium backed by Berlin.
lead_paragraph: Feeling jilted after six months of negotiations, German officials reacted angrily Wednesday to General Motors’ decision to keep its European business, Opel, rather than sell a majority stake to a consortium backed by Berlin, The New York Times’s Nelson D. Schwartz, David Jolly and Bill Vlasic reported.

headline.main: Germans Frustrated Over G.M. Keeping Opel
